p: Anopheles messeae is spread in all the lowland plains in the country and in places with stagnant waters; it is predominantly zoophilic but may also feed off humans. Anopheles messeae may transmit malaria in temperatures even below 4°C, in which case it takes 44 days for the mosquito to become infected. This is how the cases in Scotland and Norway may be explained. In Great Britain, Anopheles messeae and Anopheles atroparvus are responsible for the cases signaled by Knottnerus [ 21]. Anopheles atroparvus is spread all over the country, in areas with (more or less) salt waters, the female being predominantly anthropophilic. Anopheles atroparvus is active in temperatures starting from 15°C, when it may constitute a risk in transmitting malaria.
